description:
An odd bar

There is no sign on the entrance. For some reason, the door in the front facing the main mission street is locked, with no signs--it looks more like a backdoor. You have to enter through the door in the side-alley way in the back, which, also has no sign. You would only know if you were looking for bouncers there at night.

Inside, there are lots of weird lights, paintings on the walls, and artifacts laying around. Especially the restroom doors which had floor-to-ceiling paintings on the doors. The drinks menu also has pretty cool names for drinks.

The staff is friendly, and helpful in explaining drink options. There are plenty of tables inside, so it's not hard to find a table. The drinks are reasonably priced.

Overall, a good place to hang out and grab a beer, or a weird drink.
author: Henry L.

description:
This bar is so mis-run it's not even funny. They are painfully slow, incredibly rude, and lost my friend's credit card with no apology. They have completely incompetent bar-tenders who are actively rude and mean, shrugging off their incompetence as a joke when in reality there's no excuse as they're not that busy. 

I'm not basing this review on one visit either- I've had three consistently terrible experiences and this one was the final straw as they literally gave my friend's credit card to a random person and then gave an, "oops, we lost it" excuse when he asked to close out his tab. 

All this and they have the gall to charge $20 a cocktail! Don't waste your time, friends- you're welcome.
author: Margaret-Ann S.

description: Fun bar with good drinks. Definitely head to the little standing bar tucked in the back for craft cocktails. They whipped something really unique and citrusy... it had sesame oil in it which was oddly really good.
author: Debbie L.

description:
A pre-drink before our dinner reservation. I really enjoyed my mezcal drink called " Mexican Street Dog". A nice smokey hint from the mezcal with charcoal salt, chili, and lemon. Quiet refreshing in my opinion. 

Great space, awesome bartender, and fun vibe. I will definitely revisit this place the next time I'm in this area. I hope you give this place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
When cannot visit my favorite cocktail bars - due to distance or closure - this bar is a good stand-in (you can say it does the job #boomtish). If you're not a drinker the cocktails are good, with fun and whimsical names (what's odd to like? #boomtish}. Worn out puns aside, the cocktails are inventive here though a bit sweet for me.

Inside, the dark vibe is welcoming and not too dark. The glowing lights gives the place a lounge feel, even though the place has the wood theme of a typical bar. Other fixtures, strange contraptions, and out of place decor really differentiates it. The crowd is diverse just like the bar.

Note there are two entrances; the main one on Mission St and the side alley one on Washburn St (once entered Oddjob's bar within a bar Standing Room Only is immediately to the left).
author: Peter L.

description: Ask for the bartender Ryan, and get the Australia. It was so so so good. It's an off menu Tequila drink. Our group kept ordering rounds of it throughout the whole night. We all loved it. I was out visiting friends, so I'm sad that I won't be able to get this drink for a while. Thank you Ryan!
author: Sydney S.

description: Alaric was amazing. We were about to leave because oddjob was  closed at 12:30am that day and we came for that experience aaaaaalllll the way from LA. I lived in SF for 5 years and wanted to show him the unique experience that odd job was. Anyhow she SAVED our night. We were about to  leave and she offered us free fernet shots. So we stayed and ended up getting two more drinks each and talking to her and being entertained and having an awesome time. She was super hilarious and entertaining and one of the best bartenders in San Francisco. She really Saved our night and we will definitely be coming back tomorrow to see her.
author: Buffy S.

description:
I like this place because there are two areas - one area, you can customize your drinks and get some nice surprises by just telling the bartender your specific instructions or what mood youre feeling. You can get some pretty creative drinks here and it's always nice to see what they come up with! 

the other area has a regular cocktail menu at reasonable prices and the drinks are strong here!

It's a little dark inside but I like the booths so it's a nice place to chill and relax with friends on a Friday night if you're not feeling too wild ;)
author: Alicia L.

description: Always a good time for happy hour.  The bartenders are usually super chill.  Good prices for hh.
author: Richard T.

description:
Mamamiya, girl manager/bartender: Please get your shit together and serve with good attitude, when your customer is more polite than you, don't act like a total BITCH to her. Karma will get back to you. 
The bigger side of the venue where the female manager also served as bartender - She does NOT make you feel welcomed, and she made sure you know it. Maybe cause I am Asian? Maybe she had a bad day? But she forced me to either buy 3 drinks when I only ordered 2 loud and clear, and tried to explain to her while she didn't even start making the first drink yet... She doesn't listen at all, said to me - "Hey I am the manager here and I can make you leave, pay me 3 drinks!!!" I told her to calm down and don't get emotional, she acted like if she's on her period. 

Fire her ass please.
author: Sophie L.

description: We got so lucky to have this nugget be around the corner from our hotel. Getting around SF can be so obnoxious some times so walkability from the room is always a plus and what a find. I will never pass through town again without stopping in to tell a story.
author: Kai D.

description:
my friend loves this bar so we decided to come here on St. Patrick's day. We came around 10:20pm and there was no line. it wasn't really crowded inside either. he told me there are two parts to this bar. the right side is the bigger side with tables/booths and the main bar. the left side is the cooler side where you tell the bartender what type of drinking you want and he'll make it for you. i.e. you tell the bartender you want bacon and he'll make a drink as close to bacon as possible. if you look at the bar, you'll notice spices and other food seasoning you add to food LOL.

so of course, we went to the left side. it's cash only and we didn't bring a lot of cash so we only ordered one drink each. my friend told the bartender he wanted something light and refreshing. the bartender added a bunch of drinks into his drink. we both tried his drink and it was indeed light and refreshing. i told the bartender i wanted something berry flavored and he made me something berry flavored. the bartender said that these drinks are never duplicated and just made on the spot.

overall, i had a good experience. it wasn't too loud or crowded in this bar. the interior decor is really interesting. you can take photos with their photo booth and post your photos on their FB and IG, i think. the restrooms are interesting. one stall is a full restroom while the other stall is a half restroom. they have sinks outside the restrooms too. but there are no mirrors inside the stalls. it's a nice spot to come with a few friends. i'll be more daring and order something out of the ordinary the next time i come here!
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Oddjob has two parts to it - when you walk in, there's the main bar area to your right, as well as an intimate nook called SRO to your left. As for the main bar area, it's decent enough, with a decent menu of cocktails that are just a tad on the spendy side. An average 3-star review if there was one.

The SRO area, however, is quite the gem. The bartenders there craft customized drinks based on your mood or your specific instructions, and they can be quite elaborate drinks at that. No two drinks (at least during one visit) are the same. I observed the bartender craft an especially elaborate drink that first looked like it involved a bong, only to involve a second firey stage that had quite smokey results as far as the drink was concerned. In my case, I'm all for sweet, desserty, chi-chi cocktails, and I was pleasantly satisfied with my Thai-inspired drink, with an ever-so-slight spicy kick to it.

Especially given that the drinks on the SRO side aren't that much more expensive than at the main bar, it's to your advantage to get drinks at SRO, which is standing-room only, and then take them over to the main room where there is more seating. 3 stars for the main bar and 5 stars for SRO means a 4 star average in my book.
author: Vincent L.

description:
This is the best damn bar I have EVER been to, and with my longevity and travels, this means the basis for comparison is extensive. And it's not for the feint of heart, AA victims, or boring people. 

This isn't a wine bar. Or a brew pub. And yes, they have excellent beer and wine. What OddjobSF excels at, and basically leaves all others in the dust over are their cocktails. 

The main bar is awesome. But if you REALLY like booze turn left once you come in and revel in the glory that is SRO. And once there, talk to Aaron. He is the Yuri Geller of bartenders. I mean this guy will read your mind and nail exactly what exotic combination of booze and accoutrements will rock your world. 

I'm such a fan I frigging live across the street. Yeah, it's THAT good.
author: Jack D.

description: I love the vibe at this place! The cocktails are amazing and the Happy Hour will definitely leave you feeling far happier than you should be!  The bartenders are very friendly and are always open to offer suggestions and recommendations! Definitely recommend this place for a good local happy hour spot.
author: Neda P.

description: This is a unique bar experience, which provides  carefully mixed drinks and a playful atmosphere.  I go here over and over and it never gets old.  The drinks are unlike any other bars because they are carefully made and the manager and bartenders take pride in their work and are friendly!
author: Ghazal S.

description:
Great spot near the terrible hotel  was stuck at while gigging at the BGCA. 
A lucky find in a otherwise edgey (after dark) hood.

Dropped in with coworkers for a couple late drinks.
"Hey-Bartender" as she (the awesome bar manager) preferred to be called, served us to an educational tasting flight of some very nice Mezcals in addition to a couple rounds of their off the menu proper cocktails.

Staff was really nice to us and I enjoyed her banter and verve. The overall ambiance was on par with the nicer bars back home in DTLA with some unique SF centric features.

I'll be back. If only to try (probably unsuccessfully) convince her that all of LA isn't as completely horrible as we allow everyone one to think. Kinda like how back in Portland we tried to convince visitors not to move there and if they didn't not to tell where they were going.
author: Quin C.

description:
After dinner, my friends and I met up with some girlfriends for a round of drinks. They had been at Oddjob since around 9pm. We showed up on Friday, July 8th around 11pm. They had a table past the bar to the left.

*Number Nine: blistered red pepper rye whiskey, bitter currant reduction, burnt coco husk bitters, grapefruit, and lemon
*The Story Behind My Wooden Hand: small batch rye, dimmi herbal liquer, cynar artichoke liquer, and buddha hand bitters

My gf was already drinking the Number Nine. I decided to get The Story Behind My Wooden Hand. I liked the flavors, but there was something in it that tasted sweet to me. It might have been the white sprinkle looking things on the cocktail, but I didn't really like that element. Otherwise, I enjoyed my drink. We ordered two more cocktails, but I can't recall the names. One was bubbly and refreshing. The other looked citrusy.

The vibe is fun. It's dark, in lighting, furniture, and ambiance. Even though it can be loud, there's something intimate about the space. I really liked it. Definitely a great place to grab cocktails.
author: Elena N.

description:
Such a strange place but incredibly awesome.

My boyfriend and I walked into Oddjob for the first time on a Saturday night, only to find christmas lights strung, Rastafarian holiday music playing, and a piece of paper hung above the small side bar for "Santa's Workshop." 

This is in July.

Oddjob is odd. Like really odd. It's so odd that it's amazing. 

On Saturday nights Oddjob throws "parties" that are themed something a bit... well... odd. "Christmas in July" introduced me to the oddities of Oddjob and hooked me in.

The drinks are oddly named with interesting ingredients (Drink names: Yule Log Oldie, Milk and Cookies Shot, Crummy Hotel Room, The Story Behind My Wooden Hand). The decor is just as weird, complete with a dollar bills and a ouija board glued to the ceiling. The seating is a mixture of old schoolhouse-like desks and chairs, big red leather seats, and booths. It's dark inside but has some legit hipster lights and light fixtures, a long bar, and modern, yet weird, vibe. Overall, and oddly, it's absolutely beautiful inside. 

Joey, the manager, greeted my boyfriend and I with attitude and a smile. It fit the odd and fun environment. 

This place is absolutely something to visit and experience. I will be back Oddjob. Maybe with a party of my own to host.
author: Lori T.

description:
Great cocktails. We went earlier on sat at 7 and it was pretty empty.

Loved my cocktail. It was gin based.
author: Amit K.

description: I used to come here when it was Shine and they have really done it up so much better.  Came here on a Friday, not too packed.  They had a dj playing some gig to jams.  Cool decor.  Used, vintage items that were creatively used.  Bartenders were cool.  I ordered the Chasing sunbeams with wallace, refreshing.  I didn't get a chance to order at the cash bar Standing room only bar in the back.  I was told the bartender who makes unique drinks.  I'll be coming back to check out a drink there.
author: KB B.

description:
I'm a little embarrassed to say that my experience at Oddjob was disappointing. I've procrastinated for two years to come here, and I finally had a chance one early evening while waiting for my boyfriend to finish his workout. My first mistake was turning right when entering Oddjob, instead of left. I was intimidated that no one was in the SRO room, which later I realized from their website that this is where I wanted to go all these years.

I had a seat at the main bar and admired the peculiar (odd) decor. I noted that this would be great for private events. The dim lighting took awhile to adjust to, and it was a little off-putting. I met up with a friend, and we ordered off their constantly rotating cocktail menu. I got a whisky based one, and it was excellent! Perfectly strong and flavorful. This whole time, I didn't know how to ask the bartender about crafting a drink to my mood. (Again, I should have sat down in the OTHER room.)

I also realized that MOST bartenders (some are terrible at this) will make you any cocktail you're in the mood for. Not quite sure what makes Oddjob special in this regard, but maybe I'm just coming up with excuses to cover up for my mistakes. I'm sure Joey is talented! Either way, this wasn't an incredibly impressive place to visit. I think it's too hyped up overall, but if someone chose Oddjob as the place to meet up for a drink, I wouldn't say no!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Upon approaching the bar, a patron says "____ is the best bartender in this area." Well that tickles my fancy. Going here, I didn't know it was a made-to-your-taste kind of bar, but was excited once I see the 'tender making others personalized cocktails. 
 
Bartender: Hardly audible ramblings about what they do there.
Me: I like tequila, mezcal, citrus, spirit forward.
Bartender: Makes cocktails.
Me: Gets cocktail. Disappointed by tiki tasting punch. Pays $30 some for 2 VERY similar tasting drinks. 

The cocktail was yummy, just felt it was some standard "first time patron" sweet bs. Maybe if I talked to him more about what I wanted or made it apparent that I have booze knowledge we wouldn't have been given those run of the mill drinks.
author: Genevieve S.

description:
OMG...everything about this place rocks. Ambience: super cozy and intimate but also a fantastic time. The drinks are above and beyond what you could ask for. 

BE SURE TO CHECK OUT THE BACK BAR. The guy is incredibly knowledgeable about all liquors and spirits. You can tell him what you like or what you're feeling at that moment and he crafts a perfect cocktail...I've heard he never makes the same drink twice :)
author: Lacy D.

description:
TLDR - Chill, low-key bar with well-crafted cocktails

I liked the vibe of this spot. Pretty chill and down to earth. Interesting decor. The space is a reasonable size but there isn't much seating, especially if you have a larger group. They do take reservations so plan ahead if you have a bigger group. It was busy enough on a Thursday that my group had trouble finding a spot but not so busy that we couldn't hear each other talking, which I always appreciate in bars.

They have a creative menu of cocktails (both in name and in ingredients), all of which are $14, and some beer/wine. No food here though. I loved both of the cocktails I tried:

* DOWN THE RIVER OF MADNESS [bergamot vodka, red wine, sichuan peppercorn, bittersweet grenadine, islam, pom kernels]
* BLACK HILL TOMAHAWK [london dry gin, black keller, ginger, vanilla, pear, lemon & black salt] - loved the salt on the outside of the glass with this one

Both were lightly sweet (none of that overly sweet cocktail stuff). Neither were very strong but tasted great. Probably can't go wrong with any of the drinks here!
author: Jessie L.

description: I really like the vibe here. It's slightly eclectic without being tacky. The drinks were good. It's the perfect spot for after work.
author: Huey N.

description: As a former neighbor to Oddjob, I write this review out of longing for it back in my life. This spot is everything you (and by you, I mean I) want a bar to be. It is dark, and artsy with tasty cocktails and jazzy low-volume music. It's a solid place to share good conversation with an intimate crowd or with a date.
author: Marisa R.

description:
This place is so incredibly "San Francisco" And by that I mean cool, hip, hipster, and a little over the top. As many other reviews point out, the real draw is the small bar off to the side called Standing Room Only (SRO) which lives up to it's name. If you want to relax, I recommend you order your drink here and then go sit in the larger area of the bar. 

In SRO the bartender will create a new cocktail just for you based on pretty much whatever you want. I told him I liked bourbon or scotch and wanted something only a little sweet and he came up with something that resembled mulled wine. No idea what was in it other than scotch and there was definitely no wine. Pretty creative.

No joke though, I saw a guy come up to the bar with an origami creation and ask for something that "reflected it".  All while talking about how great Burning Man was this year. Ah SF :)
author: Erin T.

description: Came here with girlfriend to celebrate her new job. It was nearly empty during Christmas week so we could appreciate the really fun decor, great drinks too, although bartender had her back to the bar a lot cleaning so had to get her attention.
author: Inga W.

description:
The bar has a decent aesthetic and somewhat unique cocktails. However, in my one experience there, a bouncer came over at 1:45 am and removed all of our half-full drinks from the table. We didn't even have the opportunity to finish them. 

I understand the establishment needs to clean up, but having a bouncer grab your $15 cocktail out of your hands, 15 minutes before "curfew", is extremely unnerving. I'm not coming back and would not recommend.
author: Edwin D.

description: Got drinks in the back at SRO for a friends birthday and although it took a while I was super impressed by the skilled bar tender (mixologist). He made us all some unique and great drinks along with some great conversation! Great, cool bar to hang out in an otherwise lack luster area. Definitely will be back to try some more unique, fun and personalized craft cocktails!
author: Rachel N.

description:
My wife and I decided to get straight to the point with our wedding celebration. Skip the formalities of a wedding/typical sit down dinner and get the party started right away. Having strong, delicious, and well crafted cocktails was important to me while music and dancing was her priority. Oddjob was the perfect venue for this. 

Venue: 
The space itself was intimate, but big enough to host up to 125 people comfortably. Everyone had enough elbow room to drink, dance, and be married (get it?). The design and layout of Oddjob was quirky and beautiful enough such that we did not have to do anything to decorate the place besides a few personal touches which went along the theme of our celebration.

Drinks: 
The bar was fully stocked with top quality spirits, liqueur, beer, wine, and whatever you need to get your fix. They even make their own bitters and other concoctions used to make you a drink. My wife's go-to was a purple cocktail (I believe it was called Neptune?) while Joey whipped up an amazing Negroni (w/ barrel aged gin) for me all night. When I wanted to switch things up, I ordered from his amazing selection of beer and spirits! Joey was even kind enough to pour a couple fingers of a 22 year old scotch for me to celebrate my big day. It goes without saying that all of my guests enjoyed the open bar. 

Standing Room Only: 
Not only does this place serve great cocktails off their menu, they also have a small standing room only section that only fits 10-12 people where the mixologist (not bartender) will cook up the most delicious drink. Tell him/her what you like, perhaps an idea, or tell them about a dream you had and the mixologist will make you a bespoke cocktail that will make you want to celebrate your wedding there as well! 

Staff: 
From start to finish, Joey was a consummate professional. Not only is he a skilled bartender/mixologist, but he is also a wonderful bar manager and person. He and his staff went above and beyond to make sure that everything went smoothly. The only thing I had to worry about when I got there was how much fun I was going to have. 

I plan on coming back as many times as I can. My wife and I highly, highly recommend this place for anyone looking for a place to host a party, celebrate life events, dance to their heart's content, or just want a damn good drink. Do yourself a favor and check this place out.
author: Simon S.

description: This is a pretty cool space with great house special drinks and a great staff as well.  Definitely worth a stop in if you are out bar-hopping on a Friday or Saturday.
author: Jerry P.

description:
I wish there were half stars in order for me to give Oddjob a bit higher rating, lets say 3.5. I've been here a few times on Friday nights and unfortunately have the same experience on each visit. 

Don't get me wrong, the drinks are absolutely delicious - I'm a real sucker for a good cocktail with egg white, and they deliver every time. For this reason, and for the beautiful space itself they get my stars. Where they do fall short, however, is in their service. Speaking solely on the bartenders at the larger bar (I've never been to the more intimate bar located to the left of the entrance): they have a "too cool for school" attitude, it always takes about 5-10 minutes to even be acknowledged by a bartender at a relatively empty bar. The women behind the bar look at me, walk away, and continue to huddle in the corner and speak to each other rather than the costumers - this has happened to me multiple times.

There are so many other bars in SF with tasty cocktails that are created by bartenders who are happy to serve you. Oddjob's saving grace is their drinks because this is the only reason I occasionally spend my money here.
author: Adriana G.

description:
Woah woah woahhh. 

First off, there's no way you'd stumble upon this bar just walking around. It's in an alley. LOVE THAT.

We came in and didn't even bother going to the main bar to the right. We were here specifically for bar to the left. We sat at 2 seats and watched the bartender do his magic. It was interesting to see what people requested of him and then to see him execute it with an abundant of different ingredients. This bar isn't for those in a hurry. Each drink probably takes 10 minutes, so get in line and be patient waiting your turn. 

I told him I wanted something fruity with clear liquor. He made a plum puree with gin and 15 other ingredients that made for heaven in a glass!! Bf said he likes old fashioned, so he made him a version of that but with a smokey taste (actually burned something and covered the glass so it would get that smokey flavor!). 

Drinks are on the pricy end ($16) but you're coming for the experience. 

Cash only!
author: Noelle H.

description:
This is a really nice place. I'd come here for a date. Good cocktails (although somewhat pricey) and cool space. 
They have this second bar on the back, the SRO, where the bartender will make you a cocktail based on what you like (cash only here.) Very cool.
author: Marta F.

description: This is probably one of my favorite bars in the city. They always hook it up with the random cups even when they're not on the menu. AND most importantly, the drinks are delicious! The menu changes often which means you have to come here ALL THE TIME!!
author: Angela L.

description:
Really liked this bar. Loved the menus and the service was really good!

I ordered the drink with Mezcal and a smokey flavor (can't remember the name off the top of my head). I'm not a huge fan of the smokey flavor so I probably wouldn't order this drink again but everything else about the drink was great - loved the presentation too. Also enjoyed everyone else's drinks. 

Good date spot. I could definitely spend a good amount of time in this bar.
author: Ilana B.

description:
Yes-this is a pretty cool bar with a a neat idea .
I did enjoy my $20 cocktail but not enough to have a second.
The one big problem I had with this bar was the crowd and the really "cool" attitude that is everywhere.
You are not that cool, I promise, none of you!
However this is my main issue with S.F nowadays, it's been taken over by obnoxious "too cool for school" kids or tech people who is pushing everyone out. 
FYI -I am totally much cooler than all of you, I am cool personified , I am so cool people don't dare to look at me.
Anyway, I gave it four stars because I enjoyed my visit pretty much.
author: cecilia k.

description:
This is my favorite new cocktail bar! It's in kind of a hidden location but inside it's really nice. I love the big corner window seats.

The cocktail menu changes seasonally, which is cool. Each of the concoctions are carefully crafted and quite interesting. I had the Witch Doctor and it was delicious.

There's also a custom cocktail bar in the back (cash only here), where, for $16, you can have a custom cocktail made for you on the spot. It's a pretty cool process. And best of all, you get to choose one of the many beautiful glasses for your cocktail. It's a wonderful experience! I definitely recommend checking this place out.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Me: I am the typical SF transplant that has lived here for long enough that she likes to say what year she moved here, allows it sink in to her rapt listeners, and nods knowingly. I have lived here long enough to experience several painful and fruitful evolutions of this city. I have witnessed the steady river of people (by which I arrived, too), money tides that ebb and flow, the destruction and resurrection of districts. Hopeful youths saunter in and are spit out grisly shadows. I have lived here long enough to hate every neighborhood, and fallen in love again, to have tired of my old queer haunts only to mourn the closing of their doors. I am guilty of being the hypocritical, quintessential hipster-denier that feeds off newness but despises anyone encroaching on my "discovery". I thought I was jaded beyond repair, consumed by keeping both hands in the past that I may have failed to be fully in the present. All while keeping a bloodshot eye on the speckled horizon I mistook for the future. 

You: Seriously, when is she going to talk about Oddjob? Enough of this rambling, clearly she's lost it.

Me: Ok, ok. Oddjob is a place that soothes my spastic soul. It offers an intimate refuge tucked away in plain sight. The first time my husband (we're newly weds and we're queer, so read that with a little bit of a "succumbed to the heteronormative patriarchy woe is me" tone) and I went to Oddjob, it made me so happy. Cautiously happy, but happy. Dark, but not too dark. Varied music. Enthusiastic, but tempered menu. The first drink I ordered was The Whim - the bartender asked me what I liked, I said I couldn't decide between rum or tequila, he said "let's do both". I raised an eyebrow, well, both because I'm not so good at the cockeyed one eyebrow lift. It was something like a dark rum, a tequila, possibly blanco, chamomile something, tobacco something, lemon lemon, and garnished with something. It was amazing. Never had anything like it. Best cocktail of my life, for one night only. 

Come here for a casual drink, a creative drink, solo, in a group, as a couple. Come here for a post-work, I need bourbon on the rocks now. Come here to celebrate, to brood, to unwind. The bartenders are always kind, the menu is always interesting, and the crowd is never the same. I have come here dressed up, dressed down and never felt out of place. Oddjob is accepting without trying to convince you that it is ok to be yourself. 

Most recently, my husband and I had our post-wedding party here. I guess that is called a reception. Heather was our point person and she nailed it. The whole team was incredible, we got great DJs that we had heard there before, the bartenders were attentive and friendly, and we had so much fun. If you need catering or some light snacks, you can order through their sister restaurant. We had such a good time here with all our friends, I would throw another party just for fun. SF and its inhabitants never cease to surprise me. Thanks, Oddjob for existing and excelling.
author: Rikki W.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time, there was a live band playing, so it was packed. Most of the tables were reserved so me and my 6 other friends had to squeeze into a booth.

The first time I was here, I tried the customized cocktail. It was $16, which is pricey, but worth a try.

The second time we came, it was a Saturday night around 11pm and it was dead. There were maybe four or five people in the custom bar area, but the main area was empty.

My friend really likes this place, so we'll probably be back. It's a nice spot to hang out if it's not too crowded, but the drinks are meh.
author: Richa N.

description:
The most slept on bar in SF.

Twas a Saturday night and all was right in the world. we were meeting some friends for a casual, low-key night out to share some delicious cocktails, some banter and some butt-grabs. A friend of mine lives on 10th and market so we were looking for a bar nearby, and remembered my first experience at oddjob. We arrive around 9:30 to find the bar seemingly empty, decked out in Christmas decorations (which I loved) and two friendly bartenders eager to serve us.

The cocktail menu is well organized, easy to ready and is loaded with carefully planned cocktails, whiskeys and bourbons. They also have a small yet wonderful beer selection. We mentioned a fernet cocktail that we had in Portland to our bartender and he put one together that blew my mind. Oddjob reminds me of a bourbon and branch, minus the pretentiousness and hype. A wonderful IPA will set you back about $6 and a cocktail $14. The front of the room has booths running along the wall to sit and converse with friends and foes.

Overall, a chill beautiful bar without the tude and mind-blowing drinks. Ill definitely be a regular.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I'm only giving Oddjob 5 stars because I can't give them 11. This is the only bar in the city that I visit on a regular basis. And by regular I mean once a week. Okay four times a week. OKAY FINE, SEVEN DAYS A WEEK.

Everyone from the doorman, to the bartenders, to the barback are professional, hilarious, and know their shit. Drinks are always on-point, conversation is always funny, and interesting. The bartenders remember your name and your drink - they also cater to your whims and take silly pictures at the photobooth.

Stop reading and go have a fucking drink. FIN.
author: Sarah M.

description: Came during happy hour and it was packed! Still received great service. I also really enjoyed the music and atmosphere.
author: Ventana M.

description: Cool ambience. Bartenders great at presentation of drinks. SRO cool concept in theory, but actual quality of drinks really bad. From someone who really appreciates well made cocktails, the quality was very lacking. Not sure if it was just an off night or what, but definitely disappointed.
author: Kiran K.

description: Went in for drinks on a Thursday night.  I was expecting more custom cocktails but the cocktail that I got was tasty.  Wish they served food...
author: A K.

description:
The cocktail menu was pretty interesting and delicious! 
This atmosphere for this spot is definitely for smaller groups. Would not recommend for bigger parties unless you do not mind standing. I had a woman bartender and she was great...but I wish she had been a little more attentive and smiled! Other than that, I would recommend this place!
author: Jessica M.

description: Now this place is something else! A hidden gem right off Mission street, where the art of making cocktails still lives. The key here is to order the drink yourself at the first bar, right after you come in. Aaron makes your perfect drink, on the fly, based on whatever it is that's on your mind. I'm confident he has a 6th sense for this stuff. He can see right trough you, and makes you the cocktail you need, right at that moment. Just tell him whatever is on your mind, or what your looking for, without naming specific drinks and let him do his thing. Looking forward to coming back.
author: Tim B.

description: I've had a couple of my best nights in SF at Oddjob, but not recently. They used to play great hip hop dance music and attract a fun crowd. Now it's just depressing, low-key jazz/new age music and bourgeois drinks that look better than they taste. This place needs to go back to its roots. No one goes out on a Friday night to hear the dulcet tones of soft jazz.
author: Jawann S.

description:
Beautiful decor that still don't justify the prices of drinks (every single cocktail is 14$)and the impolite bartenders (plenty of people are looking for a job in the city, don't hesitate to give your job away if you don't like it).
Add to that the fact that you need to pay at least 20$ if you plan on using your credit card.
Oh and quantity wise: expect to have more ice in your drink than actual cocktail. Ridiculous. 
This place tries very hard to be cool with a very hipster decor but totally fails on the spirit. 
There is other cocktail bars WAY COOLER in the city (RYE for exemple) where you are speaking to real cocktail pros that are passionate about what they do (and offer 12$ cocktail too!!)
I won't go back or recommend this place to anybody.
author: Marion P.

description:
Grand opening tonight! 

A cool bar with minimalist wood and metal decor that's really sleek. There is seating at the bar on wooden stools with backs. It's so rare, and a big plus, to see backs on barstools. 

If you prefer cushy seating, they have a lounge area with funky little tables. Everything in this place appears to be "reclaimed."

And get this. They have a machine that makes Corpse Revivers. Seriously. If you don't know what that is, come here and get one.

Plus, there's a side area, just to the left of the door off of the alley, where you can order any drink you want (no menu) OR enjoy soft-serve from the machine. I especially like the leather wall covering and the velvet draping in that corner.

I also really like the vibe in here. The bartenders are way cool and attentive and happy to mix both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. They make a mean cucumber water! My friend's Moscow Mule was also spot on.

They have a DJ situated right next to the lounge area, spinning all sorts of hip hits to keep in tune with the overall feeling of the bar.

NOTE: There are two entrances, one on Mission Street and one off of the alley, which is Washburn Street.
author: Diana V.

description:
Excellent, excellent drinks in the back room. No menu, tell the bartender what you like, and he'll whip you up something amazing. He makes use of really unique liquors, fresh herbs, and ingredients you'd never think would taste good in a cocktail (rhubarb..? Yes, and it was delicious). 

When I had my drink, I thought it was the best of the night - I then said the same about every drink I tried afterwards! I think my favorite was one where my friend said she liked "ginger and sour". It was light, refreshing, herby, and had a twig of thyme sticking out of it. It's on the left in this photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oddjob-san-francisco?select=sPU84NAWsijEhOUUTssu6Q#sPU84NAWsijEhOUUTssu6Q

I also like that every single drink comes in its own unique cocktail glass! I don't think I saw a single glass repeated in my group that night, and between us we got maybe 9 or 10 drinks.

Be patient though - it's a pretty long wait to get your drink: there's one bartender serving a room full of eager customers. But it's only because he puts so much perfection into each drink. He's also really good at keeping track of who's been waiting the longest, so no need to jostle your way to the bar.

The bartender seemed to be friends with several customers, too. That, or he is just extra good with making friends! We caught him doing fun dance moves several times, and we made friends at the bar as well - everyone's just chill and in a good mood here.

At 8:15pm, the front room was very crowded. The back room (much smaller) had 10 or so people around the bar, and the small tables against the wall were empty so my group claimed them. We stayed until about 10:30pm - by then the front room was completely empty and the crowd had swelled and died to about 6-8 people in the back room.

Keep in mind the drinks are costly! $16 a pop, and cash only.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Aside from the sketchy location, this is a pretty good (albeit pricey) bar to chill with friends and drink some thoughtful / creative cocktails. It really is an odd bar with a mixture of decorations including tools and animals (weird combo, right). There's even an absinthe fountain (random)! 

It wasn't too crowded here on a Saturday night, which was great, because I could actually hear people talk and felt like the place was a bit more private.

Cocktails run around $12-14 each. Some of the drink names were James Bond themed, and I tried the "pussy galore."( Did they name it that just to hear you say it??) Careful,some of the drinks are quite strong, and others are more sweet. The pussy galore is a sweeter one. 

The real gem of this place is the bar to the left of they alleyway entrance where the bartender will create made to order drinks on the fly based on your preferences. I asked for an herb infused drink on the sweet side, and he made a parsnip infused cocktail with absinthe. I actually don't like either ingredient all that much, but the drink itself was AMAZING. The ingredients just went really well together. He also has a wide selection of scotch and whisky. Drinks at that bar will run around $20 each, but it's worth it to try at least once.
author: Audrey L.

description: Jubilation libations! This place was really poppin'. I came on a Friday around 6PM (or earlier) and it was already getting pretty packed. Their interior decor is really interesting and unique and industrial. It's very dim inside and there are two separate bar areas. The one left of the door is very small and smelled of incense (SRO-standing room only). I think you can host a private event in there. The one right of the door was the larger main area and had booth seating, lounge style seats and bar seats. You can reserve tables ahead of time if you like. I liked how the front door was discrete. I tried an egg white cocktail (called circus something?) and a sip of a whiskey cocktail. Both were delicious. I wish cocktails didn't cost so much these days.
author: Brenda L.

description: Dropped in with a friend for a late night drink.  Cool vibe, though the staff was a bit chilly.  If wasn't very crowded, so not surprisingly our drinks were made quickly.  They tasted as expected...good and fairly inventive.  While there was no live music the night we visited, its easy to see how this place could really step it up.  My only negative would be the staff...again, they weren't bad, just chilly.  I don't expect a "Cheers" experience, but I do expect to feel like the bar values my patronage.  Still, I'd recommend this place to friends...its worth a visit.
author: Jason G.

description:
This is a great cocktail/mixology bar right behind Twitter. It's like the artisinal counterpart to Beer Hall in the neighborhood, specializing in it's choice of alcohol and doing a great job at it.

Dimly lit, plenty of seating and a less hipster vibe to the main bar area, it's a welcome change in pace from all those speakeasy mixology bars owned by Futurebars co throughout downtown. The best part being the slightly "hidden" bar in the back where there's no drink menu

While everyone says not to miss the back bar "SRO", nerds will be attracted to the weird drink contraption thing out by the front of the main bar. This thing makes drinks?! Levers are pulled, alcohol is spilled, and then mixed into a really concentrated drink, and the cocktail also changes from time to time. 

Friendly bartenders, do yourself a favor and come by if you're in the neighborhood. Walkable from Hayes. 

Note: Cash only in a city that runs on Square & Paypal payments. I don't even..?
author: Steven C.

description: On the pricier side but if you appreciate good cocktails, it's definitely worth a visit.  Custom cocktails served in unique barware in the back. Exceptional service but expect the cocktails to take some time to make.
author: Scott N.

description:
I like the fact that Oddjob is a hidden little bar with an eclectic vibe. Also it's a bonus that they're not too crowded even for a Friday evening - A big plus for a SoMa watering hole. 

They make nice cocktails and have a decent selection of beers but my one ding is that they are a little too precious with the drinks here - even by San Francisco standards. The long wait was a common consensus of the group based on our multiple trips to the bar. Oddjob obviously takes pride in their concoctions so you'll just have to decide if it's worth your wait. Food truck parked right outside and you can bring the food into the bar which is a nice accompaniment to all the libations. 

Wondering if it's less busy on the weekend but Oddjob is definitely an option if you're looking for a meticulously crafted cocktail in the neighborhood.
author: Jon L.

description:
I LOVE these types of bars. So, how is it that I never knew about Oddjob until my friend's birthday gathering several months back?!

As many others have mentioned, the space actually houses two "separate" bars. The main Oddjob bar, which does have a menu of craft cocktails, and SRO in the back, where the drinks are custom-crafted based on your own personal likes and preferences: the latter, obviously, comes at a bit more of a premium.

The space itself is also pretty nice, with plenty of seating for larger parties (earlier in the night, anyway). Make sure to check out the neat cocktail making contraption gizmo thingy they have to the side of the main bar as well! Oh, and don't forget to bring cash: no plastic taken here.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A spacious venue, with the usual caveats associated with bar counters and stools. Otherwise, pretty accessible.

Bathroom - Didn't try them, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
OK, assuming you actually FIND this bar, enter, make an immediate left, and you're in the coolest part of the bar.

I like variety. I like to be creative. And very often, I don't like ordering from a set menu. If you're the same way, you'll love this: you sit, tell the bartender what sorts of flavors you enjoy in a drink, and five minutes later, you're granted some tasty hooch.

One of us likes sweet vodka drinks. The other prefers solid gin cocktails. The other wanted a bitter clear drink. I opted for the only whiskey mix. All of them were tasty and all a touch pricey (but worth it, in my mind). Depending on the ingredients, they vary from $14-16 per cocktail.
author: Adena B.

description: A management team that doesn't understand customer service, a back bar that thinks s glass of fernet is a high end $16 cocktail, and a "DJ" that... well, that doesn't know a hubcap from his 1s and 2s. Oddjob used to be charming because it was odd. Now it is simply a terrible, terrible excuse for a bar.
author: Arcady S.

description: Cool space but i found the back bar to be fairly pretentious. I understand the concept of custom cocktails but our drinks weren't even explained and cost $16 each. The front bar is the way to go.
author: Michael S.

description: We started on the Oddjob side for Friday HH and loved the DJ, vibe, and delightful cocktails. I had the Black Hill Tomahawk which was light, sweet, and topped off w/a salt and pepper rim. It was delightful and one of the best cocktails I've had in a while. My bf had the Etched in Stone and loved it almost as much as his go-to drink, an Old Fashioned. We then ventured to the other side for Standing Room Only. It was a lot of fun and you could tell everyone else was enjoying themselves too. Our bartender, Aaron, was very talented and we ended up staying for more drinks than planned.
author: Andrea B.

description:
What a nice surprise. Definitely lived up to the website copy -- the bespoke cocktail bar is a great find in this area, and the bouncer is great and full of personality (something I've been finding often in this city).

Brian at the cocktail bar will mix you up something based on your preferences. I had my drink -literally- smoked :) Which was mostly for the presentation and not as much for the taste, but as long as you know what you're getting, I'm totally fine with that experience.

The ambiance of the rest of the larger bar looked like it could use some work. However, there was a party right before, so maybe I should give it a shot on another night.
author: Victoria C.

description: What a joke. Waited 25 minutes at the bar and couldn't get a drink. I ended up leaving because the bartenders don't know how to work the bar.
author: Gabriel J.

description: I come here every now and then, and every time I do, the cocktail menu is completely new and every single drink on it is as inventive as the previous ones. Every drink looks and taste like a work of art. I always go for the rye, bourbon, or mezcal based drinks and have never been let down. Hard for me to remember the names of the drinks, but I remember a Briarcliff sling and Vesparum. If you're not feeling the double digit cocktails, then they also have canned Hamms and other bottles and cans. Great location. I love this place for its roominess and quiet too. It's a great place for an intimate one-on-one or meeting. Restrooms are nice and private. Interesting foot-pedal sink. Wonderful service. You can put 100% of your trust in them.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This bar is super cool!  The interior almost seems like a fun house with ceiling fixtures hanging from the side of the walls instead of on the ceilings.  Also, the bathrooms are lit up in neon colors thanks to black light and have funky characters on them.  By the way - there is a foot pedal to use the sink - I know, I couldn't figure it out either.  The drinks are fun and the bar menu itself was hand drawn and written.  A cool detail that adds to this already enjoyable bar.  The bartenders are friendly and attentive.  I really enjoyed my first time at this bar and will definitely come back again.  Thanks, Oddjob!
author: Josh S.

description:
We live 1 block away from this place but didn't even know it existed until a friend referred us.

Finally got to try it out. The bar on the right does have a cocktail menu. Drinks were really good (and they even have a drink contraption that makes a different drink every night - pretty cool!). It's also not very busy even on a Saturday night (probably because of the location) which is nice.

The bar to the left.... Now this is 5 star worthy. Joey, the bartender, makes the most delicious and intricate custom drinks. Whatever he makes looks, sounds, and tastes so delicious. The bar area is small and intimate so really leads to mingling with other guests and enjoying Joey's entertaining personality. 

Looking forward to becoming a regular :)
author: Laura D.

description: Came here after seeing a show. Live DJ. The drinks are good here. I really liked the mexican street dog drink a lot. Very refreshing. Bar is big. The side bar wasn't opened when I went though. Only 3 booths available to sit. Place is not super crowded on a Saturday night. It's off the beaten path. Plenty of street parking. They also have a camera to take pictures, which is kind of cool. Most of the artwork is also for sale here.
author: Lisa T.

description: I really enjoyed their cocktails. Everything was either great or fantastic. They have a really wide range of cocktails so you'll find something you like no matter what kind of liquor you're into. Highly recommend.
author: June W.

description:
Two Words: Cocktail Heaven. 

Despite being slightly skeptical of the location, I followed my friends into SRO at Oddjob and before I knew it was having the most enjoyable and entertaining night out in SF that I've ever had (which is saying a lot, especially since it was a Tuesday). 

What makes this place work so well is 1.) Joey and 2.) his friends, friends of friends, and complete strangers that come together to let loose, joke around, and witness cocktail magic. 

To put it simply, when it comes to crafting the perfect cocktail, Joey is a wizard. While he has an incredible array of ingredients to choose from--the thing that stands out the most is the level of imagination and heart that goes into creating them. He masterfully recreates any given mood or feeling perfectly. He also has a way of convincing you to trust him and try things you would have never considered. I specifically requested that he not use a particular ingredient, yet he insisted to use it and ended up creating one of the best drinks I've ever had. 

 In watching Joey create drinks for others, you end up befriending all of the people around you. Joey treats everyone like family, and before you know it you'll leave feeling like one. You may never know what kind of drink you'll get or the people you'll meet--but this place is guaranteed a great night out, any day of the week.
author: Lori A.

description:
Oddjob is actually 2 bars in one. Not sure if there's a separate yelp page for the bar to the left(SRO), but I think everyone refers to the location as "oddjob." 

I actually didn't get  chance to try oddjob, but I did go to the room on the left. This room has no menu and only has one bartender. You tell him some things you like and he makes a special cocktail just for you! This place is not as busy on saturday nights which worked out well since it takes the bartender some time to create each drink. The drinks are pretty expensive. They range from $15-18 and this side is cash only. 

Joey was out sick the day we went but his substitute was also a seasoned bartender. 

I feel like the left side may even be a bit too fancy for me since I'm still working on my cocktails knowledge-base. I'm still working on figuring out what spirits I like and what flavors they mix well with. If you're a cocktails connoisseur though, I think you'll love this bar. 

still not as good as the aviary, but how can you compare any bar to the aviary! D:
author: Annie Z.

description:
went to SRO (inside Oddjob, to the left) for the first time last weekend, and my usual red flags were tripping: pretentious atmosphere, arrogant bartender, slow service, and a healthy dose of hipsters.
i ordered my first drink after specifying my mood and preferences, took a sip, and was seriously impressed. Joey, good sir, you deserve those piles of kudos being heaped on you. 
bonus: Joey even made me a Zima inspired drink. how's that for hipster irony?
author: Xander C.

description:
Joey! Joey! Joey!

This is probably the most unique bar experience one can have.  The drinks are amazing! Order your own since there's no menu but rather Joey just asks you for your preferences.  He has amazing bitters, infusions, and combinations of ingredients that you're probably never heard of.  This is what happens when you never make a drink twice.  What's even more impressive is that they are all amazing.  I think between mine, and all the ones my friends ordered I sampled quite a bit and they are all great!  The bar is also super small, and everyone sort of hangs out with each other.  Reminds me of Cheers!  

Be advised though that this bar is cash only and drinks run you $16/each (which can get pricey).
author: Tiffany C.

description: Cool place, bruh
author: Shereen A.

description: Every time I've been to Oddjob, I've never had trouble finding seating so this end up being my go to bar if I want to grab a drink with a small group of friends and chat. They serve great cocktails that range from $11-14. If you have time, check out the bar SRO in the back. There's no menu and they make drinks based on preference, but the wait can be long.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Most interesting bar, EVER!

Walk into an alleyway in what used to be a sketchy part of town, and you'll find the unmarked entrance for Oddjob. Enter the door, and turn left.

See that guy behind the bar? His name is Joey, and he'll make you some AMAZING drinks.

There's no cocktail menu, and don't even think about ordering a jack&coke or a shot of fernet. Talk to Joey, and he'll ask you what kind of drinks you like. Give him some descriptions (fruity, smokey, boozey, etc) and he'll come up with a unique drink for you, on the spot.

What makes his drinks unique are the extremely interesting ingredients he uses. One of my drinks had a chantrelle mushroom-infused rye whiskey (along with a whole list of other ingredients that I can't remember now); another friend of ours had some tea-infused vodka, and so on.

$16 a drink is a bit pricey, but this place feels more like an "experience" and it's definitely worth the trip. Joey is quite an entertainer, as well... how often do you go to a bar and here lots of random chantings of people's names? JOEY JOEY JOEY!



I can't wait to go back and try some more drinks!
author: Kazu O.

description: A "hidden" jewel of SF. Old school atmosphere. Great bartenders. Super drinks. Good times. Steampunkalicious.
author: Alexander P.

description:
Super delayed review...but a great bar, nonetheless. I would never have found this on my own, if it weren't for the fact that I was meeting up with a friend.

We hung out in the back corner, with Joey in SRO (Standing Room Only), and grabbed a drink before heading off to our event. Quaint. Kitchy. Cute (not sure if that's the right word to use, but the one that first comes to mind).

What stood out to me:
* Vintage glasses
* Handmade drinks
* Housemade bitters and infused liquors

Worth checking out, if you're looking for a bar with personality!
author: Audrey C.

description:
I have such a love-hate relationship with Oddjob. In one week, I visited twice, and I had a similar experience both times. In summary? Great drinks, great ambience, great customers, strange staff.

My first stop was with coworkers after a very long Wednesday. We stopped in around 10:30 and ordered a round. The bartender was very talkative and took his time with the drinks. At last call (which was given at 11:30), three of us decided to stick around. The bartender cashed several customers out before making our drinks, so it was about 20min before we had beverages in hand. Around midnight, he came over and gave us free "shots" (which were generous 2oz+ concoctions of rye, ginger beer, and perhaps other things). Sadly, at 12:09, all of the lights came on and the bouncer started yelling for everyone to go home. I let him know we had just been given shots from the bartender, and I was told, "Well, talk to him, then." I had to finish both my drinks in ten minutes (my friends did not, leaving their free shot behind).

Despite the fact that my friend had a similar experience the following Friday (being shoved out at closing time), we decided to spend our Halloween here, making sure to leave well before closing. Most of the night was spectacular - every other guest was interesting, fun, and well-behaved. The decor was fabulous. The drinks were just as tasty. But upon ordering my second drink (read: sober), I told the bartender I had a tab open and he said, "Good for you." As a previous bartender, I responded, "Just tryin' to help, man." "What can I get for you?" I ordered a $10 vodka soda and got charged for a $15 on my final tab.

So, overall - this place just needs a few staff meetings and it might be perfect. Or maybe the snark is a San Francisco thing that this Chicagoan just doesn't understand.
author: Cassidy S.

description:
My new favorite bar! And it's less than a mile from my office (very walkable in my book), so I plan to visit often.

We came in tonight for a friend's birthday and we were all so impressed! I spent my whole time at the "Plus Plus" bar side and had a couple of the best cocktails I've ever tried. I loved Big before it closed and these are the same owners so no wonder the drinks and bartending are so perfect. 

The bartender for Plus Plus, Joey, is so personable and remembered my name for the whole night (I'll be impressed if he still know it when I come back to visit). My first drink had mint and ginger per my preferences and my second drink was a bit crazier with lot of rosemary and egg whites (both had gin). The drinks were $12 each (less than Big's pricing I think) and so worth it. 

Even the bathrooms are cool - 4 single toilet rooms for anyone to use and a beautiful communal sink. The bar is cash only but they have the fanciest ATM I've ever seen.

They are currently open Tuesday through Saturday and Joey will apparently be bartending at Plus Plus every night - yay! I can't wait to come back!
author: Meghan P.

description:
The name: curiously odd.

The bar (in terms of ambiance): not-so-odd.

The bar stools: reasonably odd. They have backs, which means you can comfortably sink in and drink for awhile. Indeed, I am a fan.

The cocktail program: deliciously odd. They're only featuring 4 or 5 cocktails at press time, but they can craft anything your palate desires.

My adventures: delightfully odd. Within two minutes of walking in, I was persuaded to take a shot of lower-grade whisky. I don't drink whisky straight, but this handsome patron was particularly convincing. Good crowd, well-mixed cocktails and a low-key atmosphere will beckon us back!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
This isn't just a bar - it's two bars.

At the main bar, they have a pretty good menu of designer cocktails. They really do a good job with novelty - I don't think there was a single cocktail that didn't have at least one ingredient I'd never heard of. The flavors of these cocktails were all good, although I didn't find any that I loved. I hear the menu also rotates occasionally, so I don't expect to run out of things to try anytime soon.

Things get really interesting, though, at the second bar. It's in a back room, has just a single bartender, and the wait for a drink here can get a bit ridiculous. I walked up to the bar just as the bartender had started serving a group of people. He noticed me waiting, and told me to just come back in 15 minutes. True to form, I went back to sit with my friends, then returned 15 minutes later. He recognized me and bumped me right to the front of the line. Great service!

So what's special about this second bar? To start, it's cash only and all drinks are $16 - expensive! But the guy working there is a cocktail savant. They've provided him with every liquor, mixer, and spice imaginable, and he'll make you anything you can dream up.

Here are three examples:
(1) I asked for something combining "whiskey and citrus". He gave me a drink with those two flavors, as well as an earthy flavor. It was quite good, and next time I'd like to try getting more specific and ask for whiskey, citrus, and floral
(2) My partner asked for "whiskey and very spicy". He made her a drink that tasted like whiskey and pineapple, with a brutal burn at the end from chili powder. She loved it!
(3) My friend, deciding to see how far he could push the envelope, asked for "blue Kool-Aid". He got it! The bartender mixed blueberry vodka, essence of lavender, and some other stuff, and boom, we had an alcoholic blue Kool-Aid. It was like magic.

This bar is pricey, but it's an ideal place to experiment and introduce your tastebuds to something new. As a bonus, on a Friday night, the main bar wasn't crowded at all! (the second bar, with only 1 bartender, still had a long wait though.) If you're in SF and want to go on a cocktail adventure, this is the place to be!
author: Dan D.

description:
This review is actually for the bar inside the bar, SRO.
I only walked through Oddjob to get there, and it wasn't really my kind of scene. At least, on the night i was there.

Standing Room Only, the real jewel here,is destination worthy.

Joey is a master at his craft, and has an amazing talent and skill in putting together flavors most people would never think of. 
I've had many ,many drinks from him, (we're regulars at the last bar he worked at.)
His drinks are always totally  balanced, and his memory for faces and names is remarkable.

We miss him being in our 'hood, but he's so incredible, he needed to spread his wings.

He is a total sweetheart, even when he's slammed, he's still charming. His drinks never disappoint. He makes the best classic drinks, but at SRO leave yourself in his hands. You will be blown away by what he comes up with.

While we can't see him every week anymore, we definitely look forward to coming back. 

***The bar remains cash only, come prepared.**
author: Amanda G.

description:
Joey & SRO (bar within the bar) = Happy Darin

I love the concept and execution by Joey. If you like cocktails and have an open palate, you will never be disappointed. His experimentation with bitters, infusions, and spirits offer endless possibilities 

Tip: don't stroll in here with a dozen of your neck beard sporting colleagues thinking this place is a great spot for an "offsite" or celebration of your latest product lunch. (This means you Square, Twitter, and Uber) The space is small, intimate and you basically screw everything up for everyone else (and yourself) when you do so.
author: Darin E.

description:
The odd job is a gem in this part of Mission Street. Nestled in a unmarked building, it is rough to spot because there is no sign and the entrance is the side door. There are two bars, one is much smaller and intimate, great for small parties. The opposite side of the bar is the main space, dim lighting, craftsman style and a bar filled with a plethora of Whiskeys, Gin, and pretty good selection of unique tequilas.

The bartenders are friendly, attentive and willing to craft any cocktail to your pleasing. There is nothing I trust more then two dudes in plaid shirts with their sleeves rolled up. And bushy beards to shake up a tasty cocktail for me. 

Downside of this bar is it is CASH ONLY, and for the times it is frustrating because who carries cash for cocktails that average $14?! It's understandable for divey bars with $7 cocktails but not a place with this type of class! They have an ATM available but you will be charged an extra fee to pull out cash. 

Drink Highlights:
Honey Rider: Bourbon, apreol, honey and lemon. This drink highlights the mix between sweet and sour, and is refreshing at the end. The Bourbon marries all the flavors to make this a tasty drink that satisfied the Bourbon/Whiskey lovers thirsty palate.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
Given their street address number, naming the bar Oddjob seems like such a missed opportunity given SF's tech centric culture.

I went last Saturday night and it was packed with an incredibly mixed crowd.  The music was loud and I couldn't tell when one song ended and the next one began; it all sounded the same (no lyrics, not really danceable, dark).  

Bottom line, it's a little too steam punk for my taste.  I half expected the bar tenders to be wearing aviator goggles.
author: Chloe M.

description: Good drinks. Quiet on a Saturday night. Friendly bartenders and endless amounts of neat machinery to oogle.
author: Caro D.

description: A nice well, designed bar great for smaller groups. They had a live DJ playing when I went and an awesome food truck right outside. They allow you to bring the food in, which was a big plus for us after work. I only wished that their beers were on tap.. They gave us bottled/canned beers poured into glasses. Overall, a great place to grab a few drinks and food with friends/co-workers. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Saachi G.

description: Great atmosphere. Great cocktails. Good people. Located in the SOMA district. Will definitely be back!
author: Chris B.

description: I'm so surprised by the high ratings and reviews because my experience there was not that great. Upon getting inside, the bar was very stuffy and dimly lit. To add to those frustrations, it took 15 minutes to get our drinks once we ordered at the bar. The bar back was the one who made our drinks. I only found out what a difference it was between the drinks the bar back made compared to how the bartender makes it when my friend ordered the same drink a second time. The taste was completely different. If my drink actually tasted how it was supposed to I'm sure it would have helped bump my rating up to 3 stars. This place also has limited seating and is pretty small.
author: Nicole Y.

description: The few times I have been here the cocktails were pretty good. The sidebar was very unique however the brunette manager of the bar could not serve drinks without displaying an extraordinarily sardonic attitude. The bar is not cool enough for me to visit again.
author: Phil W.

description: Bartender with a do-rag was rude. Plus they close at midnight (which means last call is at 11:30). Not sure if it is worth coming back here.
author: Leroy A.

description:
Classy joint.

Came with a couple of girls post dinner and we were able to get a booth. The dim lighting makes it a bit difficult to see, but really adds to the ambiance.

The craft cocktails are amazing. They also have another bar towards the back with stool seating. There's nothing odd about oddjob. Add it to your bar bucket list.
author: Shana B.

description:
+ low key vibe with plenty of seating though this may change because there wasn't a big crowd
+ fun, fancy contraption makes the specialty drink (too bad the drink tastes like black licorice)

- 4-5 drinks on the menu but the bartender can make you any drink 
- specialty drink tastes like black licorice which I don't think many people like 

Enter through the alleyway
author: Margaret R.

description: The place was ok, but all the empty tables were reserved for Tamara, and the bartender made sure we knew it.
author: Bryan D.

description:
excellent, on-point cocktails.

+ Star for a very cool space, with different zones for different parties. 
- Star for weird reservations that meant most of the seating was empty during my entire visit, and a bouncer coming down if we sat there. (If someone had ever arrived, I would change my tune, but we were there for a little over two hours on Saturday night, and several sections remained empty that entire time)
- Star for not having the extra section open/not having at least one more bartender on a Saturday night
author: Greg F.

description:
I love Oddjob, a new-ish hidden gem in SoMa.

The decor is unique and beautiful and the space is laid out really well.

Every time I've gone, the music's been perfect and most importantly, not loud enough that you have to shout your conversations.

Joey & Taylor are awesome at what they do and I usually let them decide on my drink, having never left disappointed (nor sober).
author: Teiki K.

description:
A nice addition to the Soma/Middle market scene. Please visit the back bar for some epically created cocktails. No joke you will be blown away at the crafting ability of the resident bartender. It's almost like a personality profile in a drink. 
Arrive and tell Joey your spirt of choice and your mood and he will craft the most accurate drink of this moment of your life you will ever experience. Much love to the back bar.
author: Eden F.

description:
This place sucks.  Seriously.

Besides it being expensive and pretentious the staff was super rude. 

Which is too bad because it's kind of a cool bar.  But really, don't waste your time or money.
author: Phillip M.

description:
I went to oddjob with a friend after work and we had a good time. The place was a bit empty but at least we had an easy time finding a place to sit.

They were hosting a comedian from 7-9 so we knew we weren't going to stay long.

The drink menu was amazing! I got a spicy tequila drink with smokey salt. Delish!!

Great place to hang out after a day's work.

Oh! And the bartender guys are hot!
author: Hans C.

description: You enter in from a side back alley, and there is no sign.  Mysterious!  We weren't sure what to expect but we went in anyway.  We entered and there is a nice bar to the right where they serve wine, beer and standard cocktails, plenty of space, and then to the left is a smaller bar with some seating where they (Joey was our bartender) make your cocktails special to order, where they take the time to ask you one by one what you like in a drink, what flavors you crave with whatever descriptives you can come up with that paints a picture of the perfect cocktail to you with liquor, infusions, spices and herbs.  Very charming and we loved the concept - a classy joint and lots of care is taken into the very last detail when making your drinks.  We can't wait to bring more people here!
author: Maile N.

description:
Classy cocktail bar tucked away in an unsuspecting alley... 

The decor is cool / trendy (conveyor belt bar). The space is large, and there are booths and private seating for more intimate occasions. They also have a cool drink making contraption, that fascinates everyone who watches. 

Our mixologist whipped up 2 on menu and 2 off-menu drinks, and all were equally creative and delicious. 

I'd go back!
author: Dimple B.

description:
Small space but with great drinks and a very enthusiastic bartender (the night we went at least). He was the type to ask about flavor profiles and mix something up based on your response. That might be a hit-or-miss technique for some, but it really worked out for me. He whipped up a variation of an Old Fashioned that was really yummy. Unfortunately I forget the whiskey he used. My friend wanted protein and smokiness; the result was a smoky egg-white concoction that was absolutely delicious. My sister had a super light, refreshing, and citrus-y cocktail. She's hard to please when it comes to spirits, so that really says something. The fact that all our drinks were so customized and everyone was happy with them makes Oddjob worth checking out.

The ambiance was really chill and half the space was taken up by a private party; however since we were rather early (~10 pm) the bar area was not overly crowded and there were side tables for us to occupy. I noticed it getting more crowded as we were about to leave, so they definitely can generate an audience.

Overall my impression of Oddjob is positive. It's a great place to grab drinks with a group of friends in a non-pretentious environment. Plus the fact that it's in an area (SOMA) where the nightlife is not super concentrated makes it an underrated discovery.
author: Brandy A.

description:
Most impressive!

I was in the mood for some quality cocktails after dinner in the city and Oddjob killed it.  My bro and I ordered a couple rounds between us and every concoction blew me away.  From the balance in the Nolet's based Sassafras to our bartender's original Henchman that exploded on the palate with cola, mint, black licorice, orgeat, cedar, etc., it was a fine imbibing experience.

Our bartender, Anthony, was a pleasure to chat with as well and even hooked it up with some hummus to go with our drinks.  How beyond legit is that?

While the prices are certainly on the steeper side, the creativity and skill are there in spades and I'm already looking forward to my next visit.
author: Eric F.

description: The bar manager - bartender of tonight, the girl with dark hair - a total BITCH. She forced my female friend to pay for three drinks otherwise she'll kick her out from the bar. (We only ordered two). WTF?! I was there the whole time and my female friend didn't get emotional or anything, we were being nice and reasonable the whole time, yet the bartender was acting like a total bitch, yelled at my female friend and asked her to leave just because ... Never experienced such ridiculous attitude before
author: Ryan W.

description:
Ca$h Only. Creative Cocktails. 
Hipster Bartenders. Hipster Décor. 
Large space. Little Crowd. 
Good Music. Awesome Countertop. Awesome Chandeliers. 

The only downside to this spot is that it is in a weird locale that I wouldn't normally venture to, but considering you can also hit up SRO in the same fell swoop, it is worth the trek. 

What the bartenders are doing at Oddjob and SRO is not your normal bar where drinking is a sport, here they are making drinks that are meant to be enjoyed, not devoured. 

Come one, Come all, drink some drinks, and have a ball. :)
author: Katie K.

description: Coming from Portland, Oregon where the mixology craze makes you kind of want to die, we were hesitant to check out a "cool cocktail bar" in soma. But... This place totally surprised us. While staying true to the tenderloins dumpy roots, these babes slang some tasty cocktails. Thanks for getting us drunk, oddjobs! We'll be back! Also, Joey is amazing!
author: April O.

description:
Lovedd the special cocktail bar! Ask for a crazy drink and he'll make you something amazing! Get creative and say something like "scripture on fire" n he'll try to represent it in your drink.

Gets super crowded on the weekends so go on a weekday
author: Cheri K.

description:
Yes, Joey, I'm talking at you. Look at the abundance of shining red stars this review has! Not only have you changed my perception of the drink with my name, you've also realigned my streak of getting on yelp to write less than subpar reviews. 
The concoctions you made last night had too many sophisticated ingredients for me to recall (mins the Mongolian horse wine which was elusive and surprisingly tasteful) but every step of your art was sprinkled with craftsmanship, precision, and love. 

Only disclaimer- I forgot to look at the bottom of my chair for the number 3. I'll be back.
author: Sherry W.

description:
This bar is super unique and definitely one that takes the slice. If you're lucky you will get Joey as your bartender and this guy really knows how to entertain. The cool thing about this bar is that you won't get a menu. You won't even know what to order actually, but that's okay because you don't need to know.

All you have to do is tell a story about yourself and boom, he creates the drink of your dreams. So what if you don't like it? He'll make you something else that you will like, but it keeps going until you like it. It's an amazing atmosphere and one which you can just sit back, relax with some friends, and have a great conversation with the bartender. Definitely recommend this place to anyone who loves a speakeasy bar or just one that is a little bit different than the norm.
author: Nathan L.

description: Perfect spot to have a drink- it's just a few blocks away from the Civic Center BART stop. Loved the ambiance!
author: Suzanne H.

description: Really neat place, cool atmosphere. Only stopped by once, but hope to hop in again. Cocktail aesthetic is great,
author: Annie M.

description:
One word: Joey.

Just go to Joey. Wait. Be amazed. Drink. Savor. Appreciate. Be happy.
author: Alice H.

description: We LOVE LOVE LOVE this bar. Great ambiance, delicious cocktails, never hard to park. The mixologists are spot on. We also like that it's a good place to go to chat because the music is not too loud. Seriously recommended!
author: C. L.

description:
SRO review:
I am a strong modern woman who is in charge all day, so when it comes to drinkin' time, I like it when someone else takes charge and tells me what I should drink.

Joey does just that. You say what you like. What you don't. What mood you're in. And then *poof* a magical concoction appears in front of you in beautiful glassware. He explains what unique drink he's created for you and it's like...drinks and a show. Plus he's hilarious. Like visiting a friend's house. A friend who can make a REALLY REALLY great drink.

This is a place where you taste the love and passion that was put into making the drink. You savor. You appreciate. And you think about what you want to try next.

Note, it's about $16 bucks a drink. So if you're just looking to get trashed, you can go to a place that's less good and less pricey. Also, that means you won't be taking up one of the precious seats. So more room for me!
author: Shanee B.

description: Another five star review of this bar is probably superfluous, but well deserved!  I've been in a lot of bars in a lot of cities around the world, but have never really experienced one like this before.   The cocktails are awe-inspiring, from the house-made syrups, to the top notch and/or rare liquors, to the inventive garnishes (e.g. rosemary flamed and dropped into your glass - a perfect match to the Islay Malt that formed the base of my first drink).  Joey is not the only one who can make up an awesome drink on demand.  Ashley is great at that as well! Everyone on staff was continually demonstrating their knowledge, skill, ability, and professionalism.  I will try and visit every time I am in San Francisco.
author: J M.

description:
Well, they got the name right least.  This place does an odd job of making you feel welcome.  I was completely shocked that the owners of such powerhouses like Mighty and Public Works would have such a terrible staff (especially management and security) working this bar.
